content.title: Chronic Total Occlusion Crossing Techniques
content.description: Endovascular techniques for crossing and treating chronic total occlusions in peripheral arteries, a cornerstone of limb salvage interventions.
content.definition: Chronic total occlusion (CTO) crossing involves specialized wires, catheters, and techniques to navigate through completely occluded arterial segments. Success requires understanding of wire escalation, support catheter use, re-entry devices, and alternative access strategies.

crossing_approaches: Retrograde: Access distal to occlusion, cross retrograde
support_techniques: Catheter tip deflection for directional control

learning_objectives: Apply wire escalation strategy for CTO crossing
clinical_pearls: CTO length and calcification predict crossing difficulty
Flush occlusions (no stump) are harder to cross antegrade
Subintimal crossing is acceptable if true lumen re-entry achieved
Retrograde access via pedal artery can salvage failed antegrade attempts
Patience and systematic wire escalation prevent complications
